8/ Today, as we honor the young Michiganders who were taken from us far too soon, I ask Americans across the country to join me in lifting up Oxford as the community continues to grapple with the grief and pain of this immense loss.

7/ One year later, I‚Äôm as grateful as ever to the first responders from across Michigan who leapt into action to save lives that day; to the small businesses who donated & raised money for families of the victims; and to the students who bravely spoke up in the aftermath.

6/ Sometimes grief can look like advocacy & action, which we‚Äôve seen when the students at Oxford staged a walk out to demand better gun safety laws, or through the safe gun storage legislation State Senator Rosemary Bayer has led back in Michigan as a companion bill to my own.

5/ But grief can also take the form of kindness and generosity, and we‚Äôve certainly seen that in Oxford over the last year, as families across the country have lifted this community up again and again.

4/ It looks like traumatized students, too afraid to come to school. It looks like funerals packed with teenagers. It looks like parents confused & scared about how to parent. And it looks like teachers, administrators, and elected officials trying to figure out how to lead.
3/ It‚Äôs been said that grief has a starting point but no end. Having spent many hours in this community, I know that grief comes in different forms.

2/ Madisyn Baldwin, Tate Myre, Justin Shilling, Hana St. Juliana. Their names are engraved in our memories. Although a year has passed, for the families of Oxford, their journey to healing remains a long one.
